stream_context.summary: The stream focused on implementing and debugging a new, highly optimized Mario model from artist Biobak. Kaze spent most of the time wrestling with N64 rendering limitations to correctly implement features like the cap's anti-aliased logo and shiny buttons, ultimately devising a custom software solution. He also briefly worked on a new 'light bridge' mechanic and discussed future low-level engine optimizations.

development_findings.summary: A new Mario model by Biobak was implemented that is more efficient than the original N64 model, featuring fewer triangles, a ~39% reduction in texture memory (TMEM) usage, and smaller texture dimensions.
development_findings.quote: This model here is lower poly and lower resolution than the original Mario model. And it has smaller textures than the original Mario model.

development_findings.summary: After struggling with the N64's color combiners, Kaze solved the anti-aliasing issue on Mario's cap logo by converting the texture to an indexed 4-bit (I4) format and writing C code to dynamically shift the palette's hue for power-ups.
development_findings.quote: We are using an i4 texture for his head. We could save all of this pain here by just adding 32 bytes of data to the texture. And you know what? I am doing it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze personally added a 'butt crease' to the new Mario model using vertex colors, an artistic choice he felt was necessary despite believing the model's creator, Biobak, did not want one.
development_findings.quote: So, I know Biobak didn't want a butt crease. But I feel like... he wouldn't mind... if I just... added just a little bit of a butt crease.

development_findings.summary: Kaze outlined several advanced, low-level engine optimizations he plans to implement, including predictive instruction prefetching and running OS-level functions directly from the CPU cache to avoid RAM access.
development_findings.quote: The first is in the idle thread. I'm gonna read the instruction cache and the history of which thread ran last, so I can predict the thread that runs next and prefetch instructions into iCache.

development_findings.summary: Kaze began conceptual work on a light bridge that appears when the player hits an arcade-style button, considering dithering effects for its visual implementation.
A bug where a crystal's light appeared green instead of yellow led Kaze to theorize that the engine has a limit on the number of concurrent light sources (possibly 5 or 7) that can affect an object.

context_findings.summary: Kaze compares the game's polygon budget to his childhood allowance, framing it as a constraint he is motivated to work within to prove he can achieve more with less.
context_findings.quote: This reminds me of when I was a kid. My parents would be like, your allowance is 10 euros a month. And then it's like, can I have more allowance? And then they're like, no, you have never used your allowance for anything. You just want to save up more money. And that's how I feel about the polygon budget, too.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses pride in using complex, efficient techniques (like intricate UV maps) that he believes would be forbidden in a conventional game studio, highlighting a core value of the ROM hacking scene.
context_findings.quote: I could tell with this fucking thing on the overworld but you know what, game studios would never understand. They'll never let us do this. They'll be like, just use a 32x32 please.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses a potential sponsorship from Manscaped, revealing a humorous and open approach to monetization and his public persona, and notes that team member Biobak is already involved in the creative aspect.
context_findings.quote: We are probably getting a Manscaped Sponsorship. I can talk about my shaved balls on YouTube videos next. Biobak has already given me a bunch of banger lines.

context_findings.summary: Kaze had to end the stream for a personal appointment with his wife, Zeina, at her parents' house, indicating a boundary between his work and personal life.

biobak.summary: Biobak created and delivered a new, highly optimized Mario player model that reduces TMEM usage by ~39% and has a lower triangle count than the original SM64 model.
biobak.quote: Biobak said, this model, okay, first of all, 39% reduction, TMEM time, which is amazing. And he also said this looks so much better than makes the old Mario model look like a beta model.

biobak.summary: Biobak's new model removes Mario's prominent 'protruding ass' from the original game, a design choice Kaze anticipates will be controversial among players.
biobak.quote: Move the screen square-protruding ass, sorry. People are going to be so upset about this. You have no idea. That's the one thing I think is most controversial here.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided detailed notes on his model changes, including updates to shoes, eyes, eyebrows, vertex colors, and overalls, demonstrating a thorough and communicative handover process.
Biobak was actively collaborating during the stream, sending Kaze a corrected texture file for the cap logo when Kaze's software failed to export it properly.

zeina.summary: Zeina was mentioned in a personal context, as Kaze ended the stream to attend an appointment with her at her parents' home.
zeina.quote: Unfortunately, I have to leave you guys today already. Me and Zayna have an appointment today at her parents'.

key_stories.title: The Mario Cap Logo Solution
key_stories.summary: Kaze faced a significant technical hurdle in rendering the anti-aliased 'M' on the new Mario model's cap. After his initial attempts with hardware color combiners failed, he devised a clever workaround using an indexed texture and custom C code to manage its color palette, successfully implementing the feature while maintaining performance.
key_stories.challenge: The new, highly-optimized Mario model required rendering the 'M' on the cap with anti-aliasing, a difficult task on N64 hardware without using multiple, performance-intensive rendering cycles.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to solve the problem using complex N64 color combiner configurations, but failed to achieve the desired result. After declaring that approach 'not possible,' he pivoted to a different strategy: converting the logo texture to an indexed 4-bit (I4) format and writing custom code to dynamically update its 16-color palette.
key_stories.outcome: The new solution worked perfectly, allowing the 'M' logo to be rendered with anti-aliasing in a single cycle. This approach also allows the cap's color to be dynamically changed for power-ups via C code that manipulates the texture's color palette.
key_stories.key_quote: We are using an i4 texture for his head. We could save all of this pain here by just adding 32 bytes of data to the texture. And you know what? I am doing it.

key_stories.title: The Butt Crease Addition
key_stories.summary: Kaze felt the new Mario model needed more definition on the overalls, but knew the modeler, Biobak, preferred a design without a butt crease. Kaze decided to add the detail himself, carefully adjusting vertex colors to create a subtle shading effect that he believed improved the final look, showcasing a moment of creative divergence.
key_stories.challenge: While Biobak's new Mario model was excellent, Kaze felt the overalls looked too flat and lacked detail on the back. However, he knew Biobak had intentionally created a sleeker design and likely did not want a prominent butt crease.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided to add the detail himself directly in the 3D editor. He carefully adjusted the vertex colors on the back of the overalls to create a subtle shading effect, experimenting with the darkness to ensure it didn't look like an artifact but a legitimate detail.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully added a subtle crease that was visible in-game, which he felt was a necessary improvement. The story illustrates the dynamic between a modeler's vision and the lead developer's final artistic adjustments.
key_stories.key_quote: So, I know Biobak didn't want a butt crease. But I feel like... he wouldn't mind... if I just... added just a little bit of a butt crease. You know? Just a tiny bit.
